column1: A glomus tympanum tumortympanum tumor is a tumor of the middle ear and bone behind the ear (mastoid).
A glomus tympanum tumortympanum tumor grows in the temporal bone of the skull, behind the eardrum (tympanic membrane).
- Hearing problems or loss - Ringing in the ear (pulsatile tinnitus) - Weakness or loss of movement in the face (facial nerve palsy)
Glomus tympanum tumorstympanum tumors are diagnosed by a physical examination.
Glomus tympanum tumorstympanum tumors are rarely cancerous and do not tend to spread to other parts of the body.
However, treatment may be needed to relieve symptoms.
Nerve damage can lead to facial paralysis.
